title: Factor XI Deficiency: Epidemiology and Population Distribution
short_description: Clinical overview of Factor XI deficiency, a bleeding disorder affecting both sexes equally with higher prevalence in Ashkenazi Jewish populations.
long_description: This document provides epidemiological information about Factor XI deficiency, a hereditary bleeding disorder that represents the second most common bleeding disorder in women after von Willebrand disease. The text details the demographic distribution of the condition, noting its equal prevalence between males and females across all age groups and ethnicities. Particular emphasis is placed on the significantly higher incidence rate among individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent, where approximately 8% of the population is affected. The document also provides prevalence data for the severe form of the disorder in the general population, estimated at 1 in 1,000,000 individuals.
